subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit vs. Agitator
msgSnippet: On 5/30/06, J. B. Rainsberger  wrote: ... I ve been experimenting recently with adding more custom exception classes for similar reasons,
messageBody:
On 5/30/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
...
> If Java had symbols (like Ruby does), then I would be able to have an
> exception class like OutOfRangeException ...

I've been experimenting recently with adding more custom exception
classes for similar reasons, but that wasn't a pattern I'd hit upon
when I wrote that blog entry. not sure I'll stick with it, but there
are times it seems worthwhile.

> ...and I'm not arguing that a negative score makes sense. I'm merely
> saying that without system context, it might or might not make sense for
> this class to defend itself against a negative score. It's possible that
> in the system in which it will live full time, that situation is never
> going to happen, in which case, someone /else/ (like the module that
> invokes this class) should check for such invalid data.

true, and I wouldn't check like this uniformly. but I think it is
important to distinquish between "shoudn't" and "can't" when making
the decision. there's also the question that as system evolves might
there be new callers?

> In the hands of a thoughtful practitioner, I believe Agitator to be a
> great thing. I am concerned that less-thoughtful practitioners will use
> Agitator as an excuse not to write tests. I've heard it too many times
> already. I should make it clear: that's not Agitator's fault. It's just
> a statement about the product and what it does. Any product, of course,
> can be abused.

the question of the "less-thoughtful" is something I've wrestled with
a few times while at Agitar. (the Management Dashboard is ripe for
abuse in the wrong environment.) but what I've always settled on is
that we need to focus on making the tools as useful as possible for
those with good intent, and it is better to offer those people
something a solution rather than to deny it because of how it might be
abused.

Jtf

--

http://www.developertesting.com/
